newsitem.title: USA: US money managers cut US debt exposure in week-MCM.
newsitem.headline: US money managers cut US debt exposure in week-MCM.

text.p: U.S. fixed-income managers shortened the durations of their U.S. debt portfolios in the past week, according to an MCM MoneyWatch Inc survey.

The weekly survey showed durations as a percentage of benchmark slipped to 107.5 percent--the lowest measure since November 4--in the week ended January 13, compared with 108.0 percent in the prior week.
A duration reading above 100 percent indicates the group of investors polled is mostly long on the market.
A portfolio's duration represents its average maturity and is used by portfolio managers to calculate exposure to risk.
In the "next likely move" category, portfolio managers representing 17 percent of total assets in the survey said they would "buy," compared with 31 percent the prior week.
Strategists leaning toward "sell" dipped to 19 percent, down from 27 percent in the week ended January 6.
Sixty-four percent of managers said they were "neutral" on the market, up from 42 percent a week ago.
Cash as a percentage of assets rose to 2.48 percent, against 2.21 percent registered the previous week.

The survey showed 29 percent of investors polled overweighted the 10-plus years duration sector, down from 30 percent the previous week, while 15 percent underweighted it. The remaining 56 percent were "neutral."
In the five- to 10-year duration sector, 45 percent of investors polled said they overweighted the securities and 13 percent underweighted them.
The survey included 38 domestic participants, who manage about $110 billion in fixed-income assets. The poll is conducted weekly by MCM and usually is released on Tuesday.
